stream_context.summary: Kaze blocks out and iterates on Course 11’s oil-rig/industrial platforming level: building moving platform assets (cranes, hooks, shrink/grow platforms), defining zipline and cannon traversal, and doing a major lighting pass (adding a camera-facing fill light). Mid-stream he debugs a regression that broke ziplines (caused by an earlier collision optimization he never properly tested), then checks performance/visuals on real N64 hardware where a clip-ratio optimization causes severe rendering artifacts and a graphics-thread freeze. Personal/team beats include Zeina reacting to streaming plans and sharing an early walk-cycle animation for an enemy/boss.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a project-wide lighting change inspired by Mario Odyssey, resolves a months-later regression caused by collision optimizations (revealing Kaze’s testing philosophy), and tees up a concrete plan to attempt split-screen multiplayer during an upcoming two-week vacation while validating N64 performance and uncovering a new clip-ratio rendering issue.

findings.summary: Kaze rejects the idea of a toggle for the revamped swim mechanic ("purist" vs "new"), arguing that options for fundamental mechanics are undesirable compared to accessibility options like button remapping.
He frames a core design philosophy: avoid over-instructing players (e.g., a visible cannon trajectory line), because it reduces perceived freedom and turns play into following orders.
findings.quote: I don’t want the dev telling me, ‘hey, do this.’ At that point… I’m not a player. I’m like a guy pushing buttons in a factory.

findings.summary: Major lighting change: he adds a camera-facing fill light (in addition to level light) to brighten characters/objects and improve scene readability, motivated by noticing the game looked too dark and by watching Mario Odyssey footage.

Ziplines stop working due to a regression; debugging shows the ceiling raycast/ceiling detection path was affected by a prior collision optimization. The root cause is a simple code mistake (messed-up brackets) in an optimization change he made months earlier and didn’t test.
findings.quote: I never test my code. I just assume it works… and sometimes, months later, a bug just occurs.

findings.summary: Kaze notes the Zoo area previously ran extremely poorly and was the original catalyst for his Mario 64 engine optimization work; after optimizations, Zoo performance is now much better.
findings.quote: The zoo is actually the reason I even started optimizing Mario 64.

findings.summary: On real N64 hardware, a clip-ratio change yields FPS gains (he observes ~42 FPS in one test) but also causes extreme far-geometry distortion (“melting”) and can freeze the graphics thread; he considers reverting the clip-ratio change as a stopgap.

Course 11 art direction: it’s intentionally inspired by Mario Sunshine’s Rico Harbor using recolored textures, but Kaze hoped the inspiration wouldn’t be too obvious; he iterates heavily on fog and palette to avoid the scene reading as lava/ash instead of oil/industrial grime.

He outlines Course 11 traversal building blocks: ziplines between structures must be visually unmistakable; cannons will be placed primarily at higher elevations to move between buildings, as optional traversal shortcuts rather than mandatory precision challenges.

UI/readability rationale: he placed the swim “breath meter” near/around Mario (center attention) rather than at the top HUD because players naturally focus on the character; this is constrained by N64-era UI expectations and visibility needs.
Progress status: “Buzzer 2” is the most recently finished level; the Buzzer boss fight remains unfinished pending animations. Overworlds are planned for last.

Zeina shares an in-progress walk-cycle animation for an enemy/boss and discusses constraints (keeping the head locked to always look at Mario, even if it limits natural motion). Kaze invites feedback via Discord.
Kaze reiterates he switched streaming from Twitch to YouTube because Twitch’s ad experience is “unwatchable,” and on YouTube he can control whether ads run.

He floats a concrete timebox for adding split-screen multiplayer: his job gives him two weeks of vacation at the end of June, during which he might implement multiplayer and potentially stream daily while doing it.

He intentionally seeded minor errors in his recent video (e.g., saying 37 improvements when it’s 38, duplicating a number) hoping to trigger corrective comments for the YouTube algorithm—only some mistakes were noticed.

biobak.summary: Kaze attributes the red/ashy oil look concept to Biobak, but notes too many players misread it as lava/ash, prompting palette reconsideration.

badub.summary: Kaze plays music he identifies as custom-made by Badub; he notes some tracks are Mario remixes, implying unavoidable IP-adjacent risk even if most music is original.

zeina.summary: Zeina pushes back on Kaze’s idea of streaming “all day for a week” during multiplayer development, focusing on practical household load (e.g., cooking) and expressing preference to participate via chat if streaming is intense.
Zeina presents a newly drafted walk animation, discusses how it reads (playful/toddler-ish), and aligns animation constraints with gameplay readability (always facing Mario).

findings.summary: Kaze asks Lilaa about progress on quaternion animations; Lilaa indicates it’s “done,” involving exporter-side work, which Kaze reacts to as promising.
Lilaa discusses having a large texture library (thousands), which Kaze considers a useful resource for level art iteration.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I don’t want the dev telling me, ‘hey, do this.’ At that point… I’m not a player. I’m like a guy pushing buttons in a factory.
memorable_quotes.context: Rejecting a proposed cannon-trajectory guide line; he argues it undermines freedom and player agency.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I never test my code. I just assume it works… and sometimes, months later, a bug just occurs.
memorable_quotes.context: Explaining how a months-old collision optimization mistake eventually surfaced as broken zipline ceiling detection.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: The zoo is actually the reason I even started optimizing Mario 64.
memorable_quotes.context: Connecting engine optimization motivation to a concrete in-game performance crisis.

key_stories.title: Mario Odyssey-inspired camera fill light
key_stories.summary: After watching Mario Odyssey footage, Kaze rethinks his game’s readability and adds a camera-facing fill light to brighten characters and moving objects. This is positioned as a systemic visual upgrade rather than a per-level tweak, with immediate benefits (less-dark Mario) but also new edge cases he still needs to finish (broken lighting in some areas).
key_stories.challenge: Players/comments noted scenes were hard to read because Mario/objects were too dark; Kaze also felt the game looked dim overall.
key_stories.process: He implements an additional light component that effectively comes from the camera, layered with the existing level light; he compares it to OG SM64’s camera-offset lighting feel.
key_stories.outcome: Overall game looks brighter and more readable; some lighting paths are temporarily “broken” and require follow-up fixes.

key_stories.title: Zipline regression traced to untested collision optimization
key_stories.summary: While trying to set up Course 11 traversal, Kaze discovers ziplines no longer function and treats it as a regression/QA incident. He traces the issue to ceiling detection and finds it stems from a prior collision optimization change he made months earlier, which he never properly tested.
key_stories.challenge: Mario fails to start hanging/ziplining; ceiling raycast/ceiling detection behaves incorrectly.
key_stories.process: He debugs without breakpoints (using “kill Mario” as a breakpoint), prints ceiling values, inspects raycast offsets, and reviews the collision/ceiling-finding code path until he identifies a bracket/logic mistake in the optimization.
key_stories.outcome: He fixes the code quickly, restoring expected behavior; the incident reinforces the cost of “assume it works” testing habits.
key_stories.key_quote: I never test my code. I just assume it works.

key_stories.title: N64 validation reveals clip-ratio optimization side effects
key_stories.summary: Kaze tests the updated build on real N64 hardware and confirms strong FPS, but the clip-ratio tweak introduces dramatic far-geometry distortion (“melting”) and can freeze the graphics thread. He weighs rolling back the change versus investigating the underlying cause.
key_stories.challenge: A performance optimization (clip ratio) improves FPS but destabilizes rendering on N64.
key_stories.process: He boots N64 builds, observes artifacts and a freeze, and correlates the behavior to the clip-ratio change; he frames reverting as an acceptable temporary fix while he researches the cause.
key_stories.outcome: Open technical task: determine whether the clip-ratio FPS gain is worth the rendering instability, and how to fix it properly.

key_stories.title: Two-week vacation as a multiplayer sprint window
key_stories.summary: Kaze identifies a specific upcoming time window—two weeks of paid vacation at the end of June—when he might attempt implementing split-screen multiplayer. The idea is framed as an intense, possibly daily-streamed sprint that depends on household/social bandwidth with Zeina.
key_stories.challenge: Multiplayer is a large feature requiring sustained uninterrupted focus time that Kaze normally doesn’t have.
key_stories.process: He proposes an all-day-for-a-week (or more) streaming/dev binge to “finish split-screen multiplayer,” while Zeina negotiates practical constraints and her preferred role on stream.
key_stories.outcome: Multiplayer remains tentative but is anchored to a concrete schedule opportunity, making it interview-worthy for planning and expectations.

open_questions.topic: Camera fill light rollout and edge cases
open_questions.context: Kaze adds a new camera-facing light to brighten the game but notes some areas’ lighting is “broken” until he finishes integration.
questions: What specific lighting paths or level types broke after adding the camera light, and what’s your plan to make it robust across the whole game?
How did you decide the camera light intensity so it improves readability without flattening the look or killing mood in darker levels?

open_questions.context: A months-old collision optimization mistake broke ziplines; Kaze admits he often doesn’t test changes and relies on assumptions until bugs surface later.
questions: When did you start noticing that optimizations were creating long-tail regressions, and did it change how you approach testing or review?
What would a realistic QA/testing workflow look like for a project like this—without slowing you down too much?

open_questions.topic: Clip-ratio optimization tradeoffs on real N64 hardware
open_questions.context: Clip ratio changes boost FPS but cause extreme rendering artifacts and can freeze the graphics thread on N64; Kaze considers reverting while he investigates.
questions: What exactly did you change in the clip ratio, and why do you think it destabilizes rendering on N64 specifically?
How do you decide when a performance optimization isn’t worth the visual/technical risk—especially this late in development?

open_questions.context: Kaze may attempt split-screen multiplayer during a two-week vacation and potentially stream heavily during that sprint.
questions: What’s the minimum viable split-screen mode you’d ship (camera rules, UI, level compatibility), and what would you cut if time runs out?
Which levels/systems are most likely to break with split-screen (streaming, culling, collision, HUD), based on your engine changes so far?

open_questions.topic: Course 11 readability: oil vs lava/ash interpretation
open_questions.context: Players misread the oil color as lava/ash; Kaze iterates palette, fog, and lighting to communicate “industrial oil rig” clearly while keeping the aesthetic bold.
questions: What cues do you rely on to communicate ‘oil rig’ (palette, particles, props, enemy types), and what cues were accidentally signaling ‘lava level’?
How do you balance ‘stylized/goofy’ with immediate readability on N64-era visuals where gradients and advanced fog tricks aren’t available?
